Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOSS1000 - Policy and Society","description":"

This course explores the nature of the applied social sciences and provides information about how social science can be applied to real world problems. You will be introduced to ideas about the role and use of evidence in decision-making and policy-making at local, national and international levels. We also investigate how policy is developed, changed, implemented and evaluated in applied social science domains such as social policy, public policy, criminal justice and social work. We will also discuss the practical, political and ethical problems encountered in the communication of research and expertise to inform policy and social change.


The course introduces students to key ideas, debates and issues within the social sciences in relationship to policy and practice. We develop key strategies and skills that students can apply to particular areas of employment in the key areas of public and social policy, social work and criminal justice. A series of real-world policy case studies highlighting current research will be used to illustrate the connections between policy, practice and current debates.

Students submit a 600 word fieldwork report. This is done after watching a local government meeting (either in person or online), and analysing the proceedings. The report will allow students to apply the theory learnt in the course to the real world of policy making. Students will be provided with written feedback alongside a marking rubric on their submitted work. Assessments will be marked and returned within 10 working days.

contentlets.description:
This course explores the nature of the applied social sciences and provides information about how social science can be applied to real world problems. You will be introduced to ideas about the role and use of evidence in decision-making and policy-making at local, national and international levels. We also investigate how policy is developed, changed, implemented and evaluated in applied social science domains such as social policy, public policy, criminal justice and social work. We will also discuss the practical, political and ethical problems encountered in the communication of research and expertise to inform policy and social change.

The course introduces students to key ideas, debates and issues within the social sciences in relationship to policy and practice. We develop key strategies and skills that students can apply to particular areas of employment in the key areas of public and social policy, social work and criminal justice. A series of real-world policy case studies highlighting current research will be used to illustrate the connections between policy, practice and current debates.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOSS1001 - Social Research and Society","description":"

This course introduces the methods and processes available to social scientists in researching in the social world. It explores the processes involved in locating and making sense of information used in the policy process and in generating new information through research. It Introduces and examines a range of technologies to assess the use of information and provides skills in the use of such technologies and in the design, conduct and analysis of social research.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"beb80df7db791c50eb6b147a3a9619de","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature review","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment consists of a 1000 word synthesis of literature relevant to the topic of the course.

You will receive written feedback and a numerical grade within ten working days of submission through the University's Learning Management System (LMS). The feedback sheet/rubric will be available to you at the start of the course so that you can work towards specified standards.

contentlets.description: This course introduces the methods and processes available to social scientists in researching in the social world. It explores the processes involved in locating and making sense of information used in the policy process and in generating new information through research. It Introduces and examines a range of technologies to assess the use of information and provides skills in the use of such technologies and in the design, conduct and analysis of social research.
contentlets.title: Social Research and Society

The ability to conduct high quality quantitative research is a valuable skill for social scientists and applied social researchers. This course offers you a detailed introduction to quantitative research methods and data analysis. The first part of the course elaborates on major themes in research design (e.g., measuring social concepts, sampling, data collection) and common challenges (e.g., generalisability, bias, non-response, attrition). The second part introduces you to data analysis techniques commonly used by applied social researchers. We cover: basic descriptive statistics; sampling and distributions; comparisons of means; analysis of contingency tables and categorical association; and correlations. Strategies for presenting quantitative social research data are emphasised throughout the course.

This assessment will consistent of four take-home tests. Each one will require students to submit an IBM SPSS Statistics (Statistical Software) output table plus 150 words on their interpretation of what the table means.

Students will receive written feedback and a numerical grade within two weeks of submission through the University's Learning Management System (LMS). The feedback sheet/rubric will be available to students at the start of the course so that they can work towards specified standards.

How can social research be used to influence and change policy? In this course, you will undertake a social science research project in one of several policy areas. Building on the knowledge you have acquired in research courses and on the analytical skills necessary for policy-related work, you will develop and undertake a project with an applied focus. You will independently prepare a literature review and a research proposal, conduct the research, and write a report embodying the results of the research. You will also work with a group on one aspect of the project and present an engaging summary of your research to the class. You will be actively supported by a Seminar Leader with expertise in a particular policy area.

This task involves preparing a 1500 word research proposal, which includes a literature review and an explanation of the methods to be employed.
Students will receive written feedback and a numerical grade within ten days of submission. The rubric will be available to students at the start of the course so that they can work towards specified standards.

This course asks what are some concrete ways to contribute to and influence policy? In this course, you will gain experience in dealing with 'real world' policy problems through a series of case studies on topics drawn from current policy issues. You will develop skills in problem analysis, working in groups, and oral and written communication (including submission writing). You will also develop an understanding of the practical constraints faced by social scientists working in applied policy settings.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"35c88df7db791c50eb6b147a3a9619e5","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Case Study Presentation and Discussions 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

You will prepare a 10 minute presentation or role play as defined by a Case Study Leader for a 5 week seminar series that addresses a topical policy issue. Each case study component is taught by a case study leader who is a specialist in a particular field of policy-making and will design a case study seminar that reflects real world policy practice.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"39c88df7db791c50eb6b147a3a9619e1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"61c88df7db791c50eb6b147a3a9619d9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"adc88df7db791c50eb6b147a3a9619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e9c88df7db791c50eb6b147a3a9619de","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1dc88df7db791c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Policy briefing paper 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Based on what you learn in the case study seminars, you will prepare a 1,200 word policy briefing paper that addresses the key policy issues for case study 2. Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOSS3006 - Social Sciences in the Workplace","description":"

SRAP3006 is a core course for students enrolled in the Bachelor of Social Research and Policy (BSRP) program. You must be of third year standing (ST3) to be able to take this course.


Aligned with UNSW’s emphasis on work integrated learning, this course is a structured and supported work placement designed to give you an understanding of organisational contexts through workplace or workplace-oriented experience, which uses and develops the skills gained in your studies.


Your pathway will involve a:


  • Workplace-oriented policy/research project for an organisation (this will involve placement at a host organisation internal/external to UNSW)
","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0b4e83a7db02d410eb6b147a3a961963","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project/Policy Brief","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Students are to write a policy/ project brief (2000 words) on the project the host organisation has allocated them during their internship. The project/ policy brief includes the organisational context, rationale for the project and the methods employed to complete the project. Students will receive written feedback within 10 days of submission through the University’s Learning Management System. A rubric will be provided to students at the start of the course.

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"074e83a7db02d410eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0b4e83a7db02d410eb6b147a3a961964","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"074e83a7db02d410eb6b147a3a961968","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective Evaluation","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

After completion of the Report, students will prepare a reflective evaluation (200 words) that examines the gap between their observations during their work placement and the theoretical frameworks learnt during the BSRAP courses. The Reflective Evaluation will be marked by the Course Convenor. Students will receive written feedback within 10 days of submission through the University’s Learning Management System. A rubric will be provided to students at the start of the course. This is the final assessment, for attendance purposes.

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"074e83a7db02d410eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0b4e83a7db02d410eb6b147a3a961964","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0f4e83a7db02d410eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5f4e83a7db02d410eb6b147a3a96196d","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SOSS3006.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

SRAP3006 is a core course for students enrolled in the Bachelor of Social Research and Policy (BSRP) program. You must be of third year standing (ST3) to be able to take this course.

Aligned with UNSW’s emphasis on work integrated learning, this course is a structured and supported work placement designed to give you an understanding of organisational contexts through workplace or workplace-oriented experience, which uses and develops the skills gained in your studies.

Your pathway will involve a:

  • Workplace-oriented policy/research project for an organisation (this will involve placement at a host organisation internal/external to UNSW)

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SOSS3007 - Evidence for Policy Making","description":"

In this course you will work with evidence, in the form of an existing dataset, to make sense of and seek to influence an existing policy problem. You’ll learn to interpret, analyse, and extrapolate meaningful information from an existing dataset and to contextualise your findings within a broader social and theoretical framework. You’ll learn how to apply these findings to build a case for evidence-based policy change.The application of evidence to policy making will give you an understanding of the workings of contemporary society and the development and implementation of policy, and the experience and expertise you need to be an effective policy influencer in the workplace.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3b2f8fa7db02d410eb6b147a3a96197c","name":""},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

1,500-word background essay on the policy issue under consideration. Students will receive written feedback and a numerical grade within two weeks of submission through the University's Learning Management System (LMS). The feedback sheet/rubric will be available to students at the start of the course so that they can work towards specified standards.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"332f8fa7db02d410eb6b147a3a96197d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"083f07e7db02d410eb6b147a3a96191e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

5-minute presentation to the class with key recommendation to the Minister, backed with evidence.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3b2f8fa7db02d410eb6b147a3a96197d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3b2f8fa7db02d410eb6b147a3a96197e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"403f07e7db02d410eb6b147a3a96191b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

2,500-word report to the Minister, with policy recommendation, strategically using the evidence available in the dataset provided for use.  Students will receive written feedback and a numerical grade within two weeks of submission through the University's Learning Management System (LMS). The feedback sheet/rubric will be available to students at the start of the course so that they can work towards specified standards.

contentlets.description: In this course you will work with evidence, in the form of an existing dataset, to make sense of and seek to influence an existing policy problem. You’ll learn to interpret, analyse, and extrapolate meaningful information from an existing dataset and to contextualise your findings within a broader social and theoretical framework. You’ll learn how to apply these findings to build a case for evidence-based policy change.The application of evidence to policy making will give you an understanding of the workings of contemporary society and the development and implementation of policy, and the experience and expertise you need to be an effective policy influencer in the workplace.
